title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables

Overview
What are we gonna to do today?
Today’s learning objectives

Describing and visualizing

Individual variables
Relationships between variables

Creating academic tables in Stata

Readings
The effect chapters 3 and 4

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Overview
Key concepts

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Individual Variables
Types of Variables

Continuous Variables: Can take any value within a range. Example: Income measured in currency, like ZAR.

No discrete jumps between variable values.

Count Variables: Count occurrences or items, cannot be negative and usually non-fractional.

Examples: Number of business mergers in a year.

Ordinal Variables: Categorical with inherent order but undefined magnitude of difference.

Example: Neuroticism levels (low, medium, high).

Categorical Variables: Describe observations in discrete categories with no intrinsic order.

Example: Color of flowers, with specific categories.

Binary Variables: A type of categorical variable with two categories, often ‘yes’ or ‘no’.
Qualitative Variables: Non-numeric and not easily categorized variables, e.g., text headlines.

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Individual Variables
Understanding Distributions

Distribution: Probability of values that a variable can take.

Categorical/Ordinal: Distribution shown via frequency tables or bar graphs.
Continuous: Shown using histograms or density plots.

Summary Tools:

Mean: Average value, calculated as the sum of observations divided by the number of observations.
Percentiles: Value below which a percentage of observations fall, e.g., median is the 50th percentile.

Visual Representation:

Histogram: Graphical display dividing data into bins showing frequency of values in each range.
Density Plot: Smoother alternative to histogram, representing distribution with narrowing bins.

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Relationships Between Variables
Key Concepts

A relationship in data analysis shows how two or more variables are interconnected. Understanding one variable can provide insights about another
Positive relationships imply that as one variable increases, the other tends to increase as well
Negative relationships indicate that as one variable increases, the other tends to decrease
Null relationships mean there is no discernible connection between the variables

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Relationships Between Variables
Key Assumptions

The main goal is to describe the relationship between variables accurately to address a research question
Understanding the form of a relationship (e.g., linear, quadratic) is crucial for appropriate analysis and interpretation







Causation vs. Correlation


The assumption that a scatterplot or similar visual representation can imply causation is misleading
⇢ correlation does not equal causation

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Relationships Between Variables
Conditional Distributions
Example







Definition


The distribution of one variable given a specific value or range of another variable

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Relationships Between Variables
Conditional Means




























Definition


The average value of one variable given a specific value or range of another variable ⇢ Helps understand how the expected value of one variable changes with another

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text:
Relationships Between Variables
Visualizing Relationships
Scatterplot

Basic tool to visualize relationships between two continuous variables
Plot every data point for variables on x- and y-axes to discern patterns
Example: Scatterplot between age and heart health showing a slight negative relationship

Estimation Techniques

Use of regressions to determine the nature and strength of relationships, e.g.OLS (Ordinary Least Squares): Fits a straight line, simple yet applicable for linear relationships


Conditional Distributions

Distribution of one variable given another’s value (e.g., vitamin E intake among exercisers).
Provides insights on the relationship between two variables by changing the underlying probability distribution

title: Data Exploration and Academic Tables
text: References

title: Data Analytics for Finance
text:
Welcome to the Data Analytics for Finance course materials. This website contains all the lecture slides, assignments, and resources for the course.


This course is designed to equip students with comprehensive data analysis skills using Stata and a thorough understanding of research methods in finance. The course emphasizes both theoretical foundations and practical implementation of econometric techniques essential for empirical finance research.
Students will learn how to apply statistical analysis techniques with proper understanding of underlying assumptions, interpret data effectively, and address common methodological challenges in financial research. These skills directly support students’ ability to successfully complete their master thesis replication projects and prepare them for data-intensive roles in the financial industry.



By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Data Management: Clean, transform, and merge complex datasets using different identifiers (CUSIP, GVKEY, PERMNO) in Stata
Econometric Theory: Understand and verify the assumptions underlying statistical methods used in finance research
Panel Methods: Implement and interpret fixed effects models with appropriate standard error corrections
Causal Inference: Apply difference-in-differences, event studies, and instrumental variables with proper identification strategies
Research Communication: Create publication-quality tables and essential visualizations for academic papers
Replication Skills: Execute replications of published research with proper documentation and Stata code




The course consists of 6 sessions, each lasting 2 hours 45 minutes. The sessions will be held in person on campus. The course includes individual assignments that reinforce the concepts learned in class.




Data Management and Merging
Data Exploration and Academic Tables
Regression Methods and Identification
Panel Data Methods (with DiD)
Event Studies (CAR) and Fama–MacBeth
Replication Workshop






Regular practice exercises will be posted here throughout the course.







Six assignments throughout the course
All assignments must be completed




TBD




Overall course grade ≥ 55%
Replication exercise grade ≥ 50%
All assignments must be submitted





Students will use:

Stata (version 17 or higher) - All econometric analysis
Access to financial databases through university subscriptions

All software is available through university resources. Basic familiarity with statistics is expected.






Huntington-Klein, N. (2022). The Effect: An Introduction to Research Design and Causality (2nd ed.). Chapman and Hall/CRC.

Free online version available at theeffectbook.net
Required reading for causal inference concepts
Specific chapters assigned for each session


Additional resources, recommended readings, and useful links.

Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Overview
Key concepts









Concept
Meaning
Example




Data‑Generating Process (DGP)
The complete set of rules that determine how the data you observe are created
Newton’s law of gravity


Variation
The differences in a variable’s value across observations.
How people’s incomes differ by hair color across individuals.


Identification
The process of ensuring that the variation you exploit is causal, not a spurious alternative
Choclate consumption and Nobel laureates (this is spurious)

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Overview
Why is identinfication important?
Identification is the bridge between:

Theory / prior knowledge (what we already know about the DGP)
Data (what we observe)
Causal or associational conclusions that are scientifically defensible

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Identification
What is identification?
Definition

Identification refers to the process of determining the specific variation in data that answers a research question
It involves isolating the part of the data that reflects the causal relationship of interest

Example

Estimating the effect of LLM use on exam scores1
Need to isolate variation in LLM use that is not confounded by other factors (e.g., student ability)

The gender variable is coded as 1 if the subject identifies as female, and 0 otherwise.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Identification
What are the ingredients for identification?
Key Assumptions

Data Generating Process (DGP): Assumes that observations are produced by underlying laws or processes
Theory and Assumptions: Used to identify which parts of the DGP explain the data and refine research designs
Limiting Explanation: Assumptions help block non-essential variations, focusing on the aspect of data that aligns with the research question.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Identification
Key Assumptions in DGP and Identification

Known & Unknown: Part of DGP is understood (helps form assumptions); part is unknown (area of exploration)
Theoretical Framework: Research relies on known aspects of DGP to interpret data and identify genuine causal effects
Identification Strategy: Techniques like controlling for variables, subgroup analyses, or hypothetical scenarios help test specific segments of DGP
Assumption-Based Progress: Continued research and empirical testing refine and validate assumptions about parts of the DGP

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
“DiLLMa”
What’s the story?


Motivation

LLMs are increasingly used by students e.g. for exam preparation
There is a debate about whether LLM use improves or hinders learning outcomes
Understanding the causal effect of LLM use on exam scores is crucial for educators and policymakers


Identification challenge

We have observational data on students’ LLM use and their exam scores
We need to identify the causal effect of LLM use on exam scores, accounting for potential confounders like student ability, study habits, and demographics








Research question


What is the effect of LLM use on students’ exam scores?



Libby Boxes

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Identification
What could possibly go wrong?


Naive comparison










What do we find?

Students who used LLMs scored higher on average
Naive comparison suggests a positive effect of LLM use on exam scores
Economic effect: ~0.5 point increase in exam scores








But…


Is this effect causal? Or are there confounding factors at play?

“Eye test”

The LLM group has a higher average exam scores
The groups are comparable on observable characteristics, on average1
However, there may be unobservable factors (e.g., innate ability, motivation) that differ between the groups and affect exam scores


The gender variable is coded as 1 if the subject identifies as female, and 0 otherwise.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
section: Think about it for a moment…
text: Think about it for a moment…

title: Regression Methods and Identification
section: Do unobservable factors play a role?
text:
Do unobservable factors play a role?
What about ability?

What happens if we could observe and condition on (or control for) ability?


Now, it comes in handy that I created the data myself and we can actually observe ability!

title: Regression Methods and Identification
section: Do unobservable factors play a role?
text:
Do unobservable factors play a role?
Conditional means - Ability1


Low versus high ability










What do we find?

Low and High-ability students score lower on average, when using LLMs!
The difference in exam scores between LLM users and non-users is reversed when conditioning on ability
Suggests that ability confounds the naive comparison of LLM use and exam scores



Ability is typically unobservable in real-world settings, making it a classic example of an omitted variable.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
section: Do unobservable factors play a role?
text:
Do unobservable factors play a role?
Conditional means - Let’s dissect the results


Conditional means

Unconditional means
\[
\text{LLM users: }\frac{122 \times 5.83 + 364 \times 7.45}{486} \approx 7.04
\] \[
\text{Non-users: }\frac{379 \times 6.13 + 135 \times 7.72}{514} \approx 6.55
\]
Naive effect: +0.49 (positive!)

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
What did we just discover?
Recap of findings


Results summary

Naive test: positive effect → “LLMs improve grades!”
Add ability control: effect flips negative → “Wait, no they don’t”
Conditional means plot: the reveal—LLMs hurt everyone, we were just fooled by who chooses to use them


Key insight

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Identification
Endogeneity issues
Selection Bias

Selection bias occurs when individuals self-select into treatment (LLM use) based on characteristics that also affect the outcome (exam scores)
In the example, ability influences both the likelihood of using LLMs and exam performance
This leads to biased estimates of the effect of LLM use on exam scores








Key takeaway


Naive comparisons can be misleading due to endogeneity issues like selection bias!

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Why is randomization so important?

Controlling variation in the causal variable, e.g. LLM use via random assignment
Makes sure that the treatment and control group are similar along observable and unobservable dimensions
The only difference between the two groups is the treatment
This allows us to attribute any difference in outcomes to the treatment
No selection bias (endogeneity issue)



Another term for Experiments is Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs).

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Designing and analyzing experiments
Types of experiments:

Field experiments

aim to be as similar as possible to real-world decision situations

A/B testing

aim to evaluate different versions of the same product

Lab experiments

are carried out in an artificial environment, usually a computer lab




For more in-depth information on experiments and other causal inference methods, see Békés and Kézdi (2021).

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Setup of an experiment

Random assignment of treatment via assignment rule
Number of subjects? Ideally large, exact number via power analysis

How many subjects do I need to detect a certain effect size?

Proportion of treated subjects? Ideally 50/50
Covariate balance

Did random assignment work?

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
DiLLMa experiment

Randomly assign students to LLM use or no LLM use
Ensure groups are balanced on observable characteristics (e.g., prior GPA, study habits)
Measure exam scores after the treatment period
Analyze the difference in exam scores between the treatment and control groups

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
DiLLMa experiment
Random assignment of LLM use


Naive comparison










What do we find?

Students who used LLMs scored lower on average
Naive comparison suggests a negative effect of LLM use on exam scores
Economic effect: ~0.5 point decrease in exam scores








But…


Did random assignment work? Are the groups balanced on observable & unobservable characteristics?

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Takeaways

Random assignment assures that effect is not due to selection bias
In the experiment you control…

who receives the treatment (the treatment group),…
and who doesn’t (the control group)

You can control other aspects of the situation to avoid other confounders
You can measure the effect of the treatment on the outcome
Potential trade-off between internal and external validity

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
The Skinny
What is OLS regression?

OLS is the workhorse of explanatory analytics
It lets us answer “What would happen to the expected value of \(Y\) if we changed \(X\) by one unit?”

Prediction vs explanation

Prediction: use \(X\) to forecast \(Y\)
Statistical explanation: describe the relationship between them via a functional form such as \[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \varepsilon.
\]
The coefficient \(\beta_1\) is the slope — a one‑unit change in \(X\) is associated with a \(\beta_1\) change in \(Y\).

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
The Skinny
Choosing a shape for the relationship
Linear: \[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X.
\]
“Linear‑in‑parameters” (e.g., quadratic): \[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \beta_2 X^2.
\]
Added variables and control (multi‑predictor/multiviriate OLS)
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \beta_2 Z + \varepsilon,
\] the coefficient on \(X\) is estimated using only the variation in \(X\) that is left after regressing \(Z\) out of both \(X\) and \(Y\) — that is, you “control for” \(Z\).


There are also non‑linear models: logit, probit, poisson, etc.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
The Skinny
When does it work perfectly (OLS Assumptions)?








Assumption
What it requires
Role




Linearity
\(E[Y \mid X] = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X\)
Correct specification of functional form


Exogeneity
\(E[\varepsilon \mid X] = 0\)
Ensures \(\hat{\beta}\) is unbiased and consistent


Homoscedasticity
\(Var(\varepsilon \mid X) = \sigma^2\)
Standard errors are efficient and unbiased


Independence
Observations are i.i.d.
Standard error formulas are valid


Normality (small samples)
\(\varepsilon \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\)
Validates t-tests and confidence intervals

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
The Skinny - For those who prefer plain English
When does it work perfectly (OLS Assumptions)?







Assumption
Plain English




Linearity
The relationship between X and Y is a straight line


Exogeneity
X is not correlated with anything else that affects Y


Homoscedasticity
The spread of errors is the same across all values of X


Independence
One observation doesn’t influence another


Normality (small samples)
Errors follow a bell curve—only matters for hypothesis testing with few observations

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
What dooes it look like?


Plot










Table output

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
What does the output tell me?










Component
Meaning
Typical notation




Rows (Coefficient, Standard Error)
Estimate of \(\beta_j\) and its SE (or t‑stat)
-0.021 (0.004)


Significance stars
Indicates p‑value thresholds
*** = p < .01


R²
Proportion of variance in \(Y\) explained by the model
0.033


Adjusted R²
Corrects R² for number of predictors.
0.065


F‑statistic
Joint test that all non‑constant coefficients equal zero
35.016


RMSE
Standard deviation of residuals (or “root mean squared error”)
1.307

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
How to interpret the output?


Table output




Interpretation


Slope– “For each additional location, the exam score increase by ~0.021 points.”
Precision – Given SE=0.004, even small differences in coefficients are detectable
Significance – *** indicates the coefficient differs from zero at the 1 % level
Model fit – R²≈0.065 tells us only 3.3 % of the variation in scores is captured by the predictors
t-stat – The slope is about 5 standard errors away from zero (0.021/0.004 ≈ 5), indicating strong evidence against the null hypothesis of no effect.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Statistical significance


Do not over‑interpret statistical significance; it says nothing about causal magnitude or policy relevance!

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
Takeaways

The error term separates what is explained by the predictors from everything else
Exogeneity is the linchpin that turns OLS estimates into unbiased causal indicators
Sampling variability is quantified by standard errors, which underpin hypothesis tests, p‑values, and confidence intervals
Regression tables encapsulate all of this: coefficients, precision, significance, model‑fit metrics

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
References


Békés, Gábor, and Gábor Kézdi. 2021. Data Analysis for Business, Economics, and Policy. Cambridge University Press.


Huntington-Klein, Nick. 2022. The Effect: An Introduction to Research Design and Causality. 2nd ed. Chapman; Hall/CRC.

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Theory, hypotheses, and operationalisation
What is a hypothesis?

A hypothesis is a proposed explanation for a phenomenon or a prediction of a possible causal correlation
It is a tentative answer to a research question that guides the direction of study and investigation
Its formulation is guided by existing (economic) theory
A well-constructed hypothesis is testable, meaning it can be supported or rejected through experimentation

title: Regression Methods and Identification
text:
Theory, hypotheses, and operationalisation
How do we test a hypothesis?

Stepst-testVisual



We need a baseline to test against: The null hypothesis (\(H_0\))
Why null? It states that there is no effect or no difference, which serves as a baseline assumption

\(H_0\) is what you test your \(H_1\) against, e.g. \(H_0 = 0\)
\(H_1\) is the/your alternative hypothesis - what you might believe to be true

A statistical test rejects \(H_0\) if there is enough evidence against it

If we reject \(H_0\), we accept \(H_1\)




The t-test measures how far the sample mean is away from \(H_0\)
Hypothesis:

One-sided (\(H_0 \leq 0\), \(H_1>0\)): \(t = \frac{X-0}{SE(X)}\)
Two-sided (\(H_0 = 0\), \(H_1 \neq 0\)): \(t = \frac{X_{treated}-X_{control}}{SE(X_{treated}-X_{control})}\)
